Description: Shaft of a black siltstone obelisk dedicated by Nakhthorheb to Thoth and placed before the entrance (with 523) to a shrine in a temple of the god, probably in Lower Egypt, all four faces inscribed with finely carved relief hieroglyphs giving the names and titles of Pharaoh.
Dimensions: Width: 34 centimetres (30cm down from top, original stone)
Depth: 32.80 centimetres (30cm down from top, original stone)
Curator's comments: To be included in the 'Musee achemenide virtuel et interactif' (see www.achemenet.com). Published: PM IV: pp. 73, 168 Nicholson and Shaw, Ancient Egyptian Materials and Technology (Cambridge 2000), p. 58; N. Strudwick, Masterpieces of Ancient Egypt, London 2006, pp. 286-7.

The Birch Slip records that this obelisk (and 523) were removed from their original location, the ruins of a town in the Delta, and placed before the one of the mosques in Cairo sometime in the 18th Century. [The slip actually says that it probably came from before a temple of Thoth in Lower Egypt NCS] Labelled as schist.
Acquisition name: Donated by: George III, King of the United Kingdom
